title: Sub-Angstrom Structure Determination of Organic Molecules at Room Temperature Using 100 KeV Serial Electron Diffraction
content: Finding the atomic structure of materials and molecules is crucial for understanding their properties and functions in material and life sciences. Crystallography is commonly used to determine the structure of proteins, organic and inorganic molecules, and other materials by analyzing the diffraction patterns formed when X-rays or electron beams pass through them. While X-ray crystallography has been the go-to method for many years, it requires large, well-ordered crystals, which can be challenging to obtain for certain materials like membrane proteins [1].
